p: For the patients, we further analysed whether degree of disturbance and reaction to specific consequences of climate change differed according to the type of lung disease (asthma vs. COPD/ COPD+asthma) or the presence of allergies and allergic rhinitis ( Fig 4). Patients with allergies or allergic rhinitis feel significantly more disturbed by an increased allergy risk than those without this kind of disease. Those with allergies would also avoid such risk locations to a significantly higher percentage ( Fig 4). Moreover, significantly more patients with allergic rhinitis would avoid increasing numbers of mosquitos. For all other factors the patterns were similar among all groups ( Fig 4). Finally, patients who are more symptomatic as assessed by CAT score, feel more disturbed by extreme weather events such as thunderstorms (p = 0.06, r = 0.141).
